entry.title: I need to know, if it's applicable to have approval workflow before the last step in ECP
entry.content:
We are using SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central Payroll (ECP) for a multi-country setup and would like to understand the standard SAP-supported approach for payroll approvals.
We have a business requirement for a multi-step (5‚Äì6 level) payroll approval cycle, involving Payroll, HR Operations, Finance, Country HR, and CFO, before payroll posting and bank file execution.
From our understanding, ECP does not provide a native configurable payroll approval workflow (approve/reject buttons) similar to EC workflows.
Could you please confirm:

  • Whether multi-step payroll approval workflows are supported natively in ECP, and if not,
  • What is the SAP-recommended / market best-practice approach to implement payroll approvals (e.g., Payroll Control Center, external approval tools, finance posting controls)?
  • We are specifically looking for SAP-supported and audit-accepted approaches, not custom developments unless officially recommended.

entry.title: Re: Statement Level Trigger (SQL Anywhere 17)
entry.content:
I‚Äôll restate my entire problem in case there‚Äôs a simpler solution that doesn‚Äôt require the trigger approach I initially considered.

I want to move some tables to a remote server to save space on my main database. However, the SQL statements that access these tables come from many different sources (EXEs, stored procedures, triggers, etc.), which makes it impractical to modify all of them.

To avoid changing those existing sources, I was considering creating a proxy table for each moved table and adding an INSTEAD OF trigger to handle insert, update, and delete operations. The trigger would redirect these operations to the remote table, allowing all existing SQL statements to continue working without modification.

Of course I dont have problem with insert statements, and my procedure for creating the relevant triggers looks like this:

create or replace procedure dba.MoveTableToLogDB(@TableName varchar(100), Async bit default 1)
begin
	execute immediate ('drop table  if exists dba.' || @TableName || '_LogDB');
	execute immediate ('create existing table dba.' || @TableName || '_LogDB at ''LogDB.LogDB.LogDB.' || @TableName || '''');
	------------------------Insert	
	if  Async = 1 then
		execute immediate ('' || 
		(select 'create or replace trigger "' || @TableName || '_01_Before_Insert" before insert order 1 on "dba"."' || @TableName  
		|| '" 
		referencing new as "new_rec" for each row begin ' || 
		'trigger event ExecuteImmediate(ExecuteStatement=''insert into dba.' || @TableName || '_LogDB values(''''''||' ||
		(select list('"new_rec"."' || cname || '"', '||'''''',''''''||' order by colno) from sys.syscolumns where tname = @TableName)
		|| '||'''''')''); rollback trigger; end;'
		from dummy)
		);
	else
		execute immediate ('' || 
		(select 'create or replace trigger "' || @TableName || '_01_Before_Insert" before insert order 1 on "dba"."' || @TableName  
		|| '" 
		referencing new as "new_rec" for each row begin insert into dba.' || @TableName || '_LogDB values(' ||
		(select list('"new_rec"."' || cname || '"', ',' order by colno) from sys.syscolumns where tname = @TableName)
		|| '); rollback trigger; end;'
		from dummy)
		);
	end if;
end;



create or replace event ExecuteImmediate handler
begin
	declare @ExecuteStatement long varchar;
	set @ExecuteStatement       = event_parameter('ExecuteStatement');
	execute immediate with result set on (@ExecuteStatement);
end;

entry.title: Re: SAP S4Hana Public Cloud - Custom CDS View - How do I create a view that extends Condition Record
entry.content:
Hello @JJackson

Thank you for your question

Based on what you described, it seems you might be running into potential modelling limitations. Generally sales pricing condition records can be deemed generic, basically saying  that the keys depend on the condition table. Which means a single CDS like SlsPrcgConditionRecord will not always expose Customer Group ¬Ω or Condition Table as clean joinable fields and it will not necessarily ship with an association to your product text or your sales order cubes.

I would like to better understand what you need and therefore I have some questions:

  1. Are you trying to find/define condition amount during a specific timeframe?
  2. Do you need Condition Table plus Customer Group ¬Ω keys?
  3. Is the effective price and not the master record your goal? In other words, do you really need ‚Äúwhich price applies‚Äù or to ‚Äúshow you the condition record master data‚Äù?

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: SAP Std Table Maint SE54. Add member value text in simple manner?
entry.content:
The information "Text" doesn't mean that it's the text of the displayed company, it's the label "Company" (which is shown in the tab "Texts/I/O Templates).

If you want to display the company name aside the company code, you have to create a view of type Maintenance View which joins your table and the table T001, select T001-BUTXT (names of companies), define T001-BUTXT as read-only, and create the dialog for this view.

entry.title: Common Challenges in Approving SAP Access Requests ‚Äì Practical Lessons
entry.content:
Approving SAP access requests is a daily activity in many organisations, but it is often underestimated. In several SAP security and access governance projects, access approvals have later turned out to be the root cause of audit findings and access risks.

This post shares common challenges seen during SAP access request approvals and practical lessons that can help organisations improve their approval process.

1. Unclear Role Design and Job Definitions

Access approvals depend heavily on how clearly business roles and system roles are defined. When job roles are vague or system roles are poorly named, approvers struggle to understand what access is being granted.

For example, if a user works as an accountant, the approver should easily know whether the request is for a local, regional, or global accounting role. When role names do not reflect their actual purpose, approvals become guesswork rather than informed decisions.

Lesson learned:
Clear role naming and well-defined job roles make approvals faster and safer.

2. Too Many Approval Steps

In some SAP environments, access requests go through multiple approval layers. While this may look secure on paper, it often slows down the process without improving control.

If approvers do not understand the user‚Äôs job or the role‚Äôs content, their approval adds little value. Meaningful approvals come from people who understand both the business requirement and the system access.

Lesson learned:
Fewer, well-informed approvers are more effective than many uninformed ones.

3. Accumulation of Roles Over Time

Users often change roles, projects, or departments. However, their SAP access is not always cleaned up accordingly. Over time, users collect multiple roles, which can result in excessive or conflicting access.

This ‚Äúaccess build-up‚Äù increases compliance risk and makes it difficult to understand what access a user truly needs.

Lesson learned:
Removing unnecessary access is just as important as granting new access.

4. Lack of Clear Role Ownership

A common challenge is unclear ownership of system roles. When no one is responsible for a role‚Äôs content, approvers cannot be confident that the role provides only the required access.

Role owners play a critical role in maintaining trust in the access approval process. They ensure that roles remain aligned with business needs and compliance requirements.

Lesson learned:
Every role should have a clearly defined owner who is accountable for its content.

5. Limited Visibility into Access Risks

Overlapping roles can unintentionally grant users access beyond their job needs. Without proper visibility, this ‚Äúaccess leakage‚Äù often goes unnoticed until an audit or security review.

Regular monitoring helps organisations identify risky access combinations early and take corrective action.

Lesson learned:
Access risks should be reviewed continuously, not only during audits.

Practical Recommendations

Based on experience from multiple SAP access governance initiatives, the following practices help improve access approvals:

Design system roles with clear naming and scope

Allow business approvers to reject unjustified requests

Avoid unnecessary approval layers

Review and clean up unused roles regularly

Start with minimal access and expand only when needed

Monitor access risks on a regular basis

Closing Thoughts

Access request approval is not just a technical step it is a governance decision. When roles are clear, ownership is defined, and approvals are meaningful, organisations reduce access risks and improve audit readiness.

Structured access governance and continuous reviews make SAP access management both secure and practical in daily operations.

For a more detailed discussion on SAP access approval challenges, you can read the extended version here: https://s4access.com/blogs/Typical-Challenges-in-Approving-SAP-Access-Requests

entry.title: Re: Assessing the number of messages in SAP integration S...
entry.content:
SAP doesn‚Äôt publish a simple ‚Äúper message‚Äù USD price for Cloud Platform Integration (CPI) / Integration Suite because it‚Äôs sold as subscription packages. The cost depends on the plan you choose and the number of messages included. Here‚Äôs the latest publicly available pricing guidance in USD from SAP‚Äôs Discovery Center:

üíµ SAP Integration Suite (CPI) Pricing in USD

Plan Type Monthly Subscription (USD) Messages Included per Month Notes

Starter~$1,000 / month50,0001 tenant, up to 10 custom iFlows
Standard~$3,000 / month10,0001 tenant, broader integration scenarios
Premium~$9,000 / month10,000,0004 tenants, advanced B2B/B2G features

Sources: SAP Discovery Center pricing calculator and SAP Integration Suite documentation.

‚ö†Ô∏è Important Notes

  • Overage Charges: If you exceed the included message quota, SAP bills extra per block of messages (pricing varies by contract).
  • SAP-to-SAP Integrations: Unlimited and free if you use SAP‚Äôs prebuilt content.
  • Currency: Prices are quoted in USD but may vary by region and contract terms.
  • Pay-As-You-Go (CPEA): SAP also offers consumption-based pricing where you pay per message traffic unit, typically starting around $0.007‚Äì$0.01 per message depending on volume.

entry.title: Re: Settlement rule from AUC to Final asset works only fo...
entry.content:
Hello @GabrielaTrasakova 

Thank you for your question

What you described typically happens when the AuC settlement is executed ledger by ledger. If you settle first in OL or 2L and the systems considers the run as complete, the next run can show you that there is nothing to settle although you still see values in the other ledger. In public cloud, when you use Execute Settlement for AuC, you should normally leave the Ledger field empty to post in all ledgers in one run. See  Assets Under Construction: Management and Settlement for more details.

This Blog provides some good insights: Asset Postings with Universal Parallel Accounting

Based on the fact that it does not work on one project and the others work well, this might be a configuration issue.

I suggest you:

  • Check the settlement rule, which might have been changed in the last month. Check whether the rule line is maintained only for ledger OL or only for ledger 2L. If necessary, adjust it so it applies to all relevant ledger or you may maintain rules per ledger if your process requires that. See: Ledger-Specific Settlement Rules and Parallel Accounting for more details.
  • Ensure you run the settlement correctly by leaving the ledger blank. This will ensure the posting is created for all ledgers. Then execute it.
  • If you already posted only in one ledger reverse the incorrect settlement posting and then rerun AIBU with the ledger empty.
  • You can use Display Line Items in General Ledger app to filter by Ledger =0L & 2L to confirm both of your postings exist.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Unit of measure
entry.content:
HI,

Anyone able to help in following query.

How to set up unit of measure for materials in such manner that number of decimals remains  zero.

The units of measure in question is pieces (PC).

 

Background:

There are materials for which the requirement is to handle materials as PC (pieces) with base unit of measure and CAS (case) as alternative unit of measure.  The requirement is to see the stock both in pieces (PC) and full packages (CAS).

 

We know that :

The pieces ‚ÄòPC‚Äô unit of measure is maintained via configuration via tr CUNI, via Internal unit ‚ÄòST‚Äô (MSEH1), for which External unit PC (MSEH3 - is assigned). In t Tr SPRO>SAP NetWeaver>General settings> Check units of measurement.

(In Finnish SAP GUI, the unit (MSEH1) equals as follows:

PC ‚Äòpiece ‚Äò = KPL ‚Äòkappale‚Äô

CAS ‚Äòcase‚Äô = PAK ‚Äòpaketti‚Äô. Finnish client).

 

SAP recommends to maintain the smallest possible unit of measure (PC) as base unit of measure, and the bigger unti of measure (CAS) as alternative unit of measure.

This is maintained in Material Master tr MM02, in Additional data, in ‚ÄòUnit of Measure‚Äô-sheet.

98 pieces (PC) in one case (CAS)

This set up brings value 0,010 to field AZSUB ‚ÄòNumber of Lower- Level Units‚Äô, in tr MM02 Material data>Additional data>sheet Unit of Measure. Meaning, SAP uses  three decimals in this field  Number of Lower- Level Units‚Äô, (AZSUB), instead of full decimals. In reality 98 pieces /  1 case = 0,0102040816326531. 

Now, in a withdraval of 7 pieces from the stock, via physical inventory counting , the stock quantity is being calculated as follows:

Set up details in tr MM02: 98 pcs in one (1) case

Current stock in system in tr MMBE : 980 pcs

Number of Lower- Level Units in tr MM02:  0,0102040816326531 (1 case divided by 98 pcs =  0,0102040816326531)

 

Business transation happens: Inventory counting result: 973 pcs

Outcome: SAP calculates resulting stock in PC (piece) as 973,042 (0,929 x 98 = 973,042), instead of 973, 000 pcs. Meaning, SAP uses rounded three decimal case value in the formula.

Alternative unit if measure, CAS, is  counted as 9,929  cases as follows:

0,0102040816326531  x 973 pcs = 9,928571428571466 cases. This is rounded into 9,929  cases with  3 decimals

                                          

 

What settings should be maintained in tr CUNI (Tr SPRO>SAP NetWeaver>General settings> Check units of measurement) for External unit 'PC' ? In order to fix this.

  • Choose Units of measurement>Choose Unit ST>Choose Details> Field: Decimal places (T006-DECAN)
    • SAP says ‚ÄòThis parameter determines the number of decimal places with which this measurement unit is displayed‚Äô
  • Choose Units of measurement>Choose Unit ST>Choose Details> Field: Decimal pl. rounding (T006-ANDEC).
    • SAP says ‚ÄòThe number of decimal places to which this measurement unit should be rounded.‚Äô

 

So far have used value zero in both fields, but it is not changing the functionality.

 

If there is documentation giving details for the area, would appreciate to get the links.

 

Best regards, 

Asta Usvakari

entry.title: Re: How to apply a filter on a single property of a data...
entry.content:
I made a little app/UI where I return values from our OData service for our CodeJam.

I'm able to create a list of strings and then use that to filter the list of emails.

 

I used a formula like this:

MAP(pageVars.strings,{type: "startswith", property: ["customer"], value: item.mystring})

Of course you will get the filter values from your app variable

entry.title: SCC- Mudan√ßa na Gest√£o contributiva S.S. / Change in the contributory management of Social Security
entry.content:
English Version below

Sum√°rio executivo

A Simplifica√ß√£o do Ciclo Contributivo (SCC) introduz um novo modelo de comunica√ß√£o de remunera√ß√µes e apuramento de contribui√ß√µes que elimina a tradicional Declara√ß√£o de Remunera√ß√µes (DR). A Seguran√ßa Social passa a calcular automaticamente as obriga√ß√µes contributivas de cada trabalhador, cabendo √† entidade empregadora apenas confirmar, alterar ou complementar os valores antes de proceder ao pagamento.

O resultado √© uma redu√ß√£o significativa de burocracia, maior previsibilidade de encargos e transpar√™ncia para empresas e trabalhadores.

Publica√ß√£o: Anuncio da Simplifica√ß√£o do ciclo contributivo pela Seguran√ßa Social(20 de Novembro de 2025).

 

Objetivos das mudan√ßas legais e da ado√ß√£o da Plataforma de Interoperabilidade

  • Automatizar o apuramento mensal de contribui√ß√µes, libertando as empresas de tarefas repetitivas.
  • Garantir coer√™ncia dos dados atrav√©s da recolha direta de v√≠nculos, taxas, absentismo das baixas e remunera√ß√µes existentes na Seguran√ßa Social.
  • Fomentar a utiliza√ß√£o da Plataforma de Servi√ßos de Interoperabilidade (PSi) para uma integra√ß√£o segura entre os sistemas de Recursos Humanos e a Seguran√ßa Social, sobretudo para entidades com 10 ou mais trabalhadores.
  • Padronizar prazos:
    • Confirma√ß√£o/altera√ß√£o de valores at√© dia 20 do m√™s seguinte.
    • Pagamento das contribui√ß√µes entre dia 1 e 25.
  • Refor√ßar a transpar√™ncia e fiabilidade do registo contributivo dos trabalhadores, com consulta em tempo real no Portal da Seguran√ßa Social.

Ver v√≠deo de apresenta√ß√£o

 

Principais altera√ß√µes legais (Decreto-Lei 127/2025 & Decreto Regulamentar 7/2025) ‚Äì s√≠ntese

Apresentamos a s√≠ntese dos diplomas legais, sendo que o ponto 2 √© o que impacta na localiza√ß√£o da SAP, derivado de referir-se √° Declara√ß√£o de remunera√ß√µes (art. 40.¬∫ CC):

  1. Comunica√ß√£o de admiss√£o de trabalhadores (art. 29.¬∫ CC & art. 5.¬∫ DR):
    • Passa a ser realizada exclusivamente via Seguran√ßa Social Direta/PSi.
    • Prazo reduzido: at√© ao in√≠cio da execu√ß√£o do contrato (antes: 15 dias antes).
    • Presun√ß√£o de v√≠nculo em falta cai de 12 meses para 3 meses.
  2. Declara√ß√£o de remunera√ß√µes (art. 40.¬∫ CC, 20.¬∫, 13.¬∫-A, DR):
    • Substitui√ß√£o da entrega da DR por aceita√ß√£o/confirma√ß√£o de valores apurados pelo sistema.
    • Confirma√ß√£o obrigat√≥ria at√© dia 20; omiss√£o equivale a aceita√ß√£o autom√°tica.
    • Novas contraordena√ß√µes para falta de confirma√ß√£o/corre√ß√£o (limite de 60 dias).
    • Deixa de se poder utilizar o c√≥digo ‚Äú6‚Äù da declara√ß√£o de remunera√ß√µes, havendo obriga√ß√£o de entrega de declara√ß√£o de substitui√ß√£o
    • As entidades empregadoras com menos de 10 trabalhadores podem efetuar as comunica√ß√µes e declara√ß√µes no servi√ßo da Seguran√ßa Social Direta.
  3. Pagamento (art. 43.¬∫ CC)
    • Novo intervalo: dia 1-25 do m√™s seguinte (antes 10-20).
  4. Suprimento oficioso (art. 40.¬∫-A CC; arts. 27.¬∫-30.¬∫ DR)
    • Seguran√ßa Social pode lan√ßar remunera√ß√µes em falta com base nos seus dados, notificando a entidade empregadora.
  5. Regras de tempos de trabalho (art. 16.¬∫ DR; art. 70.¬∫ CC)
    • Equival√™ncia de 1 dia por cada 5 h em regimes √† hora/parciais; m√°x. 30 dias/m√™s.
  6. Calend√°rio de ado√ß√£o
    • Ades√£o volunt√°ria: 1 jan 2026 ‚Üí 31 dez 2026 (irrevers√≠vel).
    • Obrigat√≥rio para todas as empresas a partir de 1 jan 2027.

 

Impacto em SAP

A mudan√ßa referida no ponto 2 das altera√ß√µes legais impacta diretamente o processo de envio das remunera√ß√µes hoje coberto pelo report standard RPC_PAYPT_DRI.

A seguran√ßa Social estabelece que a comunica√ß√£o deve ser feita via Web Service atrav√©s da Plataforma de Servi√ßos de Interoperabilidade. Caso a entidade tenha menos de 10 trabalhadores, pode tamb√©m faz√™-lo atrav√©s do portal da Seguran√ßa Social.

No mundo SAP, a grande maioria das empresas utilizadoras, ter√° sempre que gerar as declara√ß√µes totais porque o mais habitual √© a grande maioria dos empregados ter pagamentos var√°veis e absentismos desconhecidos pela seguran√ßa social.

Assim a SAP est√° em contacto permanente com a Seguran√ßa Social para avaliar todos os servi√ßos SCC que exigem integra√ß√£o, tal como para esclarecer as d√∫vidas que surgem nestes servi√ßos.

Estamos neste momento a analisar, quais os servi√ßos que iremos disponibilizar (os mais relevantes), e o esfor√ßo para que em breve seja anunciada a data de entrega destes servi√ßos relevantes para as empresas nossas clientes, tendo como objetivo melhoria do processo.

N√≥s iremos manter este documento atualizado

EN Version

 

Executive Summary

Executive Summary

The Simplification of the Contributive Cycle (SCC) introduces a new model of reporting of remuneration and clearance of contributions that eliminates the traditional Remuneration Declaration (DR). Social Security automatically calculates the contributory obligations of each employee, and it is up to the employer only to confirm, change or supplement the values before proceeding with the payment.

The result is a significant reduction in red tape, greater predictability of burdens and transparency for businesses and workers.

Publication: Social Security announcement of Contributive Cycle simplification (November 20th, 2025)

 

Objectives of legal changes and adoption of the Interoperability Platform

  • Automate monthly contributions clearance, freeing companies from repetitive tasks.
  • Ensure consistency of data through direct collection of employment relationships, contribution rates, sick leave absenteeism and remunerations, available in Social Security.
  • Foster the use of the Interoperability Services Platform (PSi) for a secure integration between Human Resources systems and Social Security, especially for entities with 10 or more workers.
  • Standardize deadlines:
    • Confirmation/change of values until the 20th of the following month.
    • Payment of contributions between the 1st and 25th.
  • Strengthen the transparency and reliability of the contributory register of workers, with real-time consultation on the Social Security Portal.

See the presentation Video

 

Main legal changes (Decree-Law 127/2025 & Regulatory Decree 7/2025) ‚Äì summary

In the following, a summary of the legal acts is presented; the 2nd point is the one that impacts the localization of SAP, as it refers to the Remuneration Statement (art. 40 CC):

  1. Communication on the admission of workers (Article 29 CC & Article 5 DR):
    • To be carried out exclusively via Direct Social Security/PSi.
    • In case of reduced term: until start of contract execution (before: 15 days before).
    • Presumption of missing employment relationship drops from 12 months to 3 months.
  2. Remuneration statement (Article 40 CC , article 20.¬∫& article 13.¬∫-A, DR):
    • Replacement of Remuneration Statement delivery by acceptance/confirmation of the values determined by the system.
    • Confirmation required by day 20; omission is equivalent to automatic acceptance.
    • New regulatory offences for missing confirmation/correction (60 days limit).
    • It is no longer possible to use code ‚Äú6‚Äù in the remuneration declaration, and there is an obligation to submit a replacement declaration.
    • Employers with fewer than 10 employees may submit communications and declarations through the Social Security Direct service.
  3. Payment (Art. 43 CC)
    • New interval: day 1-25 of the following month (before 10-20).
  4. Own supply (Art. 40a CC; Rules 27-30 DR)
    • Social Security can post missing remunerations based on their data and notify the employer entity.
  5. Working time rules (Art. 16 DR; Art. 70 CC)
    • Equivalence of 1 day for every 5 hours in hourly/partial regimens; max. 30 days/month.
  6. Timetable for adoption
    • Voluntary adoption: 1 Jan 2026 ‚Üí 31 Dec 2026 (irreversible).
    • Mandatory for all companies as of Jan 1, 2027.

 

Impact on SAP

The change referred to in point 2 of the legal changes directly impacts the process of sending the remuneration today covered by the standard report RPC_PAYPT_DRI.

Social Security states that communication must be done via the Interoperability Services Platform via Web Service. If the entity has fewer than 10 employees, it can also do so through the Social Security portal.

In the SAP world, most user companies will have to generate the all statements because usually most employees have variable payments and other absence events unknown to Social Security.

SAP is therefore in permanent contact with Social Security to evaluate all SCC services that require integration, as well as to clarify any questions that arise in these services.

SAP is currently assessing which of the services to provide (the most relevant) and the effort involved, so as to soon announce the respective delivery date of these relevant services, with the aim of improving the processes for SAP customers.

We will keep this document update!!

entry.title: What‚Äôs New in SAP HANA Cloud ‚Äì December 2025
entry.content:
As the year draws to a close and the holiday season is approaching, we‚Äôre excited to share one more set of updates before 2025 wraps up. The Q4 release of SAP HANA Cloud delivers a focused set of innovations designed to further improve operational efficiency, resilience, developer productivity, and more.

Let‚Äôs deep dive into key innovations included in the December 2025 release:

 

SQL Tools for Administration in SAP HANA Cloud Central

Property Graph Viewer in Database Administration Tooling

With the Q4 release, SAP HANA Cloud Central introduces a property graph viewer directly within the database administration tooling. This viewer allows you to visually explore property graphs, where entities are represented as vertices and relationships as edges. A common example is modeling airports as vertices and flight routes as directed edges, including properties such as distance. You can apply filters to vertices and edges and enhance their analysis by applying built-in graph algorithms like neighborhood exploration, shortest path, or Cypher-based filtering.

The main value of the property graph viewer is faster understanding of complex relationships stored in graph structures. Instead of relying on raw query results, you can visually explore how entities are connected and quickly identify patterns, dependencies, or anomalies. This makes graph data more accessible not only to technical experts but also to solution architects and analysts who benefit from an intuitive, visual representation of relationships.

SQL Console Background Activities

SQL console background activities enable long-running SQL statements to continue executing independently of the browser session. You can now start a statement, close the browser, and return later to review the results without interrupting execution. This capability is fully integrated into the database administration tooling in SAP HANA Cloud Central.

This feature removes a long-standing friction point when working with complex or time-consuming SQL workloads. Administrators and developers no longer need to keep browser sessions open or worry about accidental disconnects. As a result, productivity increases, and operational tasks such as data preparation, analysis, or maintenance queries become more reliable and less disruptive.

Automatic Saving and Loading of SQL Statements

The SQL console now automatically saves its contents and connection details and restores them when you return. This behavior can be configured in the settings, allowing you to decide how persistent their SQL console sessions should be.

This enhancement provides continuity when switching tasks or sessions. You can pick up exactly where you left off, without re-establishing connections or recovering lost SQL statements. It improves day-to-day efficiency and reduces context switching, especially for administrators and developers working across multiple systems.

Application for Schemas and Deployment Infrastructure Containers

A new application in the database administration tooling provides a consolidated view of schemas and SAP HANA deployment infrastructure (HDI) containers within a subaccount. These can optionally be grouped by their associated SAP HANA database instance. You can examine detailed metadata, including Cloud Foundry organization and space information, instance IDs, and links to the associated database. From there, you can directly navigate to the database instance or open a SQL Console or database explorer connection.

This application simplifies landscape transparency for administrators. Instead of piecing together information across tools, you can quickly identify where schemas and containers live, understand their context, and jump directly into analysis or troubleshooting. This is especially valuable in larger environments with many applications and database instances.

 

Multi-Model and Machine Learning Updates

With the Q4 2025 release of SAP HANA Cloud, we continue to strengthen embedded Machine Learning and AI capabilities across the Predictive Analysis Library (PAL), the Automated Predictive Library (APL), and the Natural Language Processing (NLP) Services. These enhancements focus on making advanced analytics easier to use, more consistent across scenarios, and better suited for real-world business data.

Key highlights of this release are:

  • A new unified time series procedure, serving developers to utilize the same interface across different times series algorithms
  • text embedding model enhancements, supporting output vector dimensionality reduction, while maintaining retrieval accuracy
  • a new cross encoder model with the NLP services, for accurately re-ranking search results
  • text column input, text embedding operators with AutoML classification and regression models
  • text tokenization enhancements supporting regular expression token filtering and a new text log parsing function for detecting and determining new log pattern
  • the HANA ML experiment monitor UI now supports visual model monitoring and drift analysis

To learn more about the new Multi-Model and Machine Learning updates, check out @ChristophMorgen‚Äòs blogpost here.

Transforming Property Graphs into Knowledge Graphs

With the Q4 2025 release, SAP HANA Cloud introduces the ability to transform property graphs into knowledge graphs. This capability allows you to convert existing graph structures into a semantic, knowledge-graph representation without redesigning your data models from scratch. It enables you to work with different graph paradigms on top of the same underlying data.

This innovation helps you maximize data utility by seamlessly switching between property graph and knowledge graph models depending on your needs. You are no longer restricted to a single data representation and can choose the most appropriate graph model for analytics, reasoning, or integration scenarios. As a result, you gain greater operational efficiency, improved interoperability between graph models, and more flexibility in how you explore and reuse graph-based data.

Learn more about transforming property graphs into knowledge graphs on this blogpost by @shabana .

 

Calculation View Modeling Updates

Column Lineage Insights for Graphical Calculation Views

SAP HANA Cloud now allows you to gain column lineage insights for graphically modeled calculation views by calling an SQL table function. This capability provides transparency into how output columns are derived from underlying sources, with lineage tracked across graphical modeling steps and stopping at functions or procedures.

By making lineage information easily accessible, this feature improves model quality and trust. Developers can better understand complex models, speed up enhancements, and reduce errors during refactoring. For architects and analysts, clearer lineage increases confidence in the data and supports governance and audit requirements.

Input Parameters for Currency and Unit Conversion in MDS Cubes

Input parameters can now be used to specify client values for currency and unit conversion when working with multidimensional services (MDS) cubes. These values no longer need to be materialized, and conversions can be defined dynamically at query runtime.

This enhancement increases flexibility in analytical scenarios. You can adapt conversions based on runtime context without redesigning models or creating additional persisted data. It enables more dynamic reporting and simplifies scenarios where conversion logic depends on user input or business context.

Restricted Columns in MDS Cubes

With Q4, restricted columns can be added to MDS cubes and evaluated at query execution time. If runtime evaluation is not possible, deployment fails with a clear notification. This approach avoids mandatory materialization of input parameters while still ensuring correctness.

The key value lies in greater runtime control and reduced data preparation overhead. You can now influence how restricted columns are processed without forcing early decisions during modeling, leading to more flexible cubes and more efficient execution.

Visibility of Key Columns When Modeling Joins

When defining joins in calculation views, key columns are now visually indicated. This makes it easier to understand join semantics and identify important relationships directly in the modeling UI.

By highlighting key columns, this feature helps you create star joins with greater confidence and accuracy. It reduces modeling errors, improves data consistency, and ultimately results in higher-quality analytical models.

Left Outer Joins in Star Joins of MDS Cubes

SAP HANA Cloud now supports left outer joins in star joins for MDS cubes. This expands the range of scenarios that can be modeled using multidimensional services.

The benefit is faster adoption of MDS cubes in additional analytical use cases. You gain more flexibility in how dimensions and facts are combined, without having to fall back to alternative modeling approaches.

If you are interested in discovering more about Calculation View modeling updates, check out this blogpost by @JanZwickel.

 

Cloud Reliability and Total Cost of Ownership

The Q4 release of SAP HANA Cloud is also introducing significant enhancements to strengthen the service's reliability while reduction the overal total cost of ownership at the same time.

Multi-Region Disaster Recovery

In early Q4 we extended disaster recovery capabilities beyond multiple availability zones within a single region to selected, distant regions. The initial scope focused on North America, using Amazon Web Services with a pairing between US East (VA) and US West (Oregon). Support includes SAP HANA Cloud Data Lake Files, while multi-tenancy is excluded in the initial phase.

This innovation significantly improves resilience against regional outages. By maintaining a secondary system in a distant region, customers can better protect critical workloads and ensure business continuity. The offering starts with a defined scope and will expand stepwise to additional regions, cloud providers, and features.

We're happy to share, that we will be extending our offering to Europe, early in January 2026. Customers will then be able to protect SAP HANA Cloud workloads across EU Central (Frankfurt) and EU South (Milan), improving resilience against regional outages with a secondary system in a predefined, geographically distant region. This expansion will help EU-based and global customers strengthen business continuity while meeting regional availability and data residency needs, with additional regions and enhancements planned based on demand.

Active/Active Read-Enabled High Availability

Synchronous replicas in a "high availability" configuration ensure increased reliability via autonomous failover capabilities to standby systems, in case of outages or other incidents.
But, such high availability setups require redundant resources, which traditionally remain idle during normal operations. With the new active/active read-enabled option, SAP HANA Cloud allows these secondary systems to actively handle read-intensive analytical workloads. In the initial scope, client-side statement routing enables applications to direct analytical queries to these replicas.

This approach improves cost efficiency and performance at the same time. You can offload analytical workloads from the primary system while still preserving full high-availability readiness. The same resources that ensure resilience now also deliver day-to-day business value.

Automatic Up-Scaling Storage

SAP HANA Cloud now supports automatic storage upscaling to prevent disk-full situations. When enabled by administrators, the system can double the initially provisioned storage size - up to a customer-defined maximum - once usage reaches 98%. Alerts notify administrators, and a minimum cycle time of six hours applies between scaling events.

This capability helps avoid critical outages caused by full disks while still keeping costs under control. Administrators gain more time to react to growing storage needs and can define clear boundaries for automatic scaling, balancing safety and predictability.

 

Seamless Integration with  SAP Business Data Cloud

As announced at SAP TechEd 2025, SAP HANA Cloud will integrate in a bi-directional manner with SAP Business Data Cloud, to consume and produce data products and thereby combine the best out of two solutions. While the production of data products will become available in early 2026, the consumption is now possible with our latest release.

Native Consumption of Data Products

SAP HANA Cloud can now directly consume data products from SAP Business Data Cloud. Virtual table connections are created automatically, enabling seamless access from SAP HANA Cloud to the data product source.

This integration allows customers to extend SAP line-of-business applications with custom logic while relying on governed, reusable data products. It reduces integration effort and accelerates innovation by making enterprise data easier to access and combine.

 

Enhancements to SQL on Files

Delta Table Replication

Direct read-only access to Delta tables in the object storage or through Delta Sharing, which has been introduced since QRC 04/2024, has offered real-time analytics on the vast volume of data in files, without moving them into SAP HANA Cloud. With QRC 04/2025, it evolves further by offering replication capability for critical datasets, enabling faster queries with greater flexibility and robust data management.

This new Delta table-to-HANA replication offers granular controls, such as chunk-based initial load, which allows splitting the data into multiple chunks and loading them separately to make the initial load more manageable. Furthermore, when it comes to Change Data Capture (CDC), it allows either user-driven, version-based CDC or system-driven, scheduled CDC for full automation. 

To learn more about SAP HANA Cloud‚Äôs new Delta table-to-HANA replication, take a look at @SeungjoonLee's blog post here.

Smart Data Access: Support for two new remote sources through Data Access Agent

Additionally, based on the newly introduced Smart Data Access (SDA) Data Access Agent from the last QRC 03/2025, read-only access to two new remote sources, Google Sheets and Oracle Database in the cloud, will be available from QRC 04/2025. 

The way of configuring and using them remains the same as for other previously supported remote sources, and for newly provisioned Data Access Agents, all new adapters are activated by default. To activate new adapters for a Data Access Agent that has already been provisioned and is currently in use, please refer to SAP Note 2600176 - SAP HANA Smart Data Access Supported Remote Sources for further details on how to activate them, as well as additional information on support. 

 

Datacenter Updates

In Q4 2025, we are announcing the availability of SAP HANA Cloud in these new BTP regions:

  • Italy (Milan) on AWS 
  • Germany (St. Leon-Rot) on SCI 
  • United Arab Emirates (Dubai) on SCI 
  • US West (Colorado) on SCI* 
  • Australia (Sydney) on SCI* 

* General availability is expected by the end of Q4 2025, when the respective BTP regions are planned to go live. See SAP Roadmap Explorer for details.

We continue our journey to give customers the freedom to choose their preferred infrastructure cloud provider by investing in regions on both hyperscalers and SAP Cloud Infrastructure (SCI). 

  • On AWS, we are announcing the availability of SAP HANA Cloud in a second European region: Italy (Milan). This establishes the technical foundation for multi-region disaster recovery within European borders. 

The first SCI region ‚Äî Germany (Frankfurt) ‚Äî was announced in Q3 2025, see blog post. Now, we are making SAP HANA Cloud available globally on SCI, by offering a second SCI region in Germany (with EU Access), as well as SCI regions in the U.S., Australia, and the UAE.

 

Further Updates

Native Multi-Tenancy: Tenant Move with Reduced Downtime

The enhanced tenant move process for SAP HANA Cloud native multi-tenancy splits the operation into a preparation phase and a short cutover phase. During preparation, tenant data is copied while the source tenant remains fully operational. Only during the final cutover is brief downtime required to apply delta changes and switch over.

This significantly reduces business downtime and gives you control over scheduling the cutover in low-impact time windows. It improves operational flexibility and minimizes risk during tenant reorganization.

Selective, Incremental Migration to SAP HANA Cloud

Selective, incremental migration allows you to migrate chosen parts of an SAP HANA 2.0 database to SAP HANA Cloud instead of moving everything at once. Migrations can be performed in smaller, manageable steps based on schemas or deployment infrastructure containers.

This approach reduces downtime, avoids migrating unused components, and makes large migrations more predictable. It allows you to better plan the transition to the cloud, while minimizing disruption.

Rule-Based Index Advisor

The new rule-based Index Advisor analyzes query usage patterns to identify index optimization opportunities. It recommends creating or dropping indexes for single-table filter queries and provides ready-to-execute SQL statements.

By automating index analysis, this feature improves performance while helping control costs. Administrators gain actionable insights without deep manual analysis, making database tuning more accessible and efficient.

Thanks for taking the time to explore the What‚Äôs New in SAP HANA Cloud on Q4 2025 innovations!

If you‚Äôd like to go deeper into the technical details of the December 2025 release, we recommend visiting the What‚Äôs New Viewer in the technical documentation. It provides a comprehensive overview of the full release scope. To stay informed about upcoming innovations, announcements, and best practices, follow the SAP HANA Cloud tag.

You can also find our latest blog posts by searching for the #whatsnewinsaphanacloud hashtag.

If you missed earlier What‚Äôs New webinars, you‚Äôll find recordings of past sessions and upcoming events in our YouTube playlist. Our What‚Äôs New webinar covering the Q4 2025 innovations will be posted on this playlist very soon.

Do you have questions about SAP HANA Cloud or want to share your thoughts on the new features?
Join the conversation in the SAP HANA Cloud Community Q&A or leave a comment below. We‚Äôd love to hear from you!

Enjoy the holidays and have a great start into 2026!

entry.title: Adding an Additional Procedure to Existing Serial Number Profile with Stock ‚Äì Impact

Hello SAP Community,

We have a question regarding Serial Number Profile configuration in SAP S/4HANA Cloud.

In our productive system, we would like to add an additional procedure (ADVR) to an existing serial number profile that is already assigned to materials with available stock.

Important points:

  • The serial number profile itself will remain unchanged
  • Only an additional procedure is appended
  • Existing serial numbers and stock data are not intended to be altered

As per general SAP guidance, changing serial number profiles for materials with stock is not recommended.
In SAP Note 3132393, the proposed approach includes:

  • Removing all stock from storage locations
  • Changing the serial number profile
  • Reposting the stock afterward

However, this process is not feasible in our productive environment.

From a configuration perspective, this is more of a procedural extension rather than a profile change, so we would like to understand how the system behaves in this scenario.

My questions to the community:

  • Has anyone added an additional procedure to an existing serial number profile with stock in S/4HANA Cloud, public edition?
  • Did you experience any technical issues or inconsistencies with existing stock or serial numbers?
  • Is the stock-clearing approach in Note 3132393 strictly required only for profile changes, or does it also apply to procedure extensions?

 

Any insights, best practices, or real-life experiences would be greatly appreciated.

SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 

@Caner_Demircan

entry.title: Re: Can the result of CALL TRANSFORMATION be empty?
entry.content:
1. Lines 6 to 8: is it possible that without error the XML is empty?
    • The XML is always filled after a successful transformation.
    • So, testing if the generated XML is empty or not makes no sense.
  2. Lines 11 and 16: isn't the generated XML always empty if there's an error, why testing if it's empty?
    • The XML can be partially filled after an exception because the transformation transforms field by field directly in the result variable. See the demonstration program (ABAP Unit / Run via Ctrl + Shift + F10).
    • But testing if the XML is empty or not after an exception makes no sense 99% of the time.
  3. Line 12: why considering that the attribute S2 is filled in all cases when the exception CX_XSLT_RUNTIME_ERROR is raised, and why not using LO_ERROR->GET_TEXT( ) instead?
    • CX_XSLT_RUNTIME_ERROR is a generic exception with many possible texts as can be seen in SE24 (tab "Texts"), and these texts use S2 or not:
      CX_ROOT An exception occurred
      CX_TRANSFORMATION_ERROR The command CALL TRANSFORMATION triggered an exception
      CX_XSLT_EXCEPTION XSLT Exception
      XSLT_NOT_SUPPORTED XSLT is not (yet) supported on this platform
      CX_XSLT_RUNTIME_ERROR XSLT runtime error
      OUTPUT_SETTING_CONFLICT Conflict in output definition '&S2&', attribute '&S1&'
      IMPOSSIBLE_SECONDARY_RESULT Secondary result &AS1&1 cannot be created
      CONVERSION_IMPOSSIBLE Value '&S1&' cannot be converted to type '&S2&'
      UNSUPPORTED_CALL Form of function call for '&S1&' not supported
      BAD_KEY Invalid key '&S1&'
      BAD_URI Invalid document URI '&S1&'
      INVALID_PREFIX No declaration in scope for namespace prefix in '&S1&'
      NO_NODESET Value '&S1&' is not a nodeset
      PARSE_ERROR XML parsing error (&I1&) in '&S1&', line &I2&, column &I3&: &S2&
      UNKNOWN_OBJECT Unbound external object '&S1&'
      OUT_OF_MEMORY Out of memory
      NO_TREEFRAGMENT Value '&S1&' is not a tree fragment
      NO_TRANS_VALUE Not bound to a transformation
      PROGRAM_LOST XSLT program lost
      VAL_STACK_OVERFLOW Value stack overflow
      TRANS_VALUE Bound to a transformation
      SRC_STACK_OVERFLOW Source-context stack overflow
      RES_STACK_OVERFLOW Result-context stack overflow
      BAD_RESULT_CONTEXT No valid result context supplied
      BAD_PROGRAM No valid XSLT program supplied
      BAD_INTERNAL_VALUE Illegal internal value for external call
      BAD_EXTERNAL_VALUE Illegal external value from external call
      ACT_STACK_OVERFLOW Activation stack overflow
      BAD_SOURCE_CONTEXT No valid source context supplied
      INTERNAL_ERROR Internal error
      UNKNOWN_FUNCTION Call of unknown function
      FORMAT_ERROR Invalid XML format
      PROPVALUE_ERROR Invalid property value
      NOT_SUPPORTED Serialization is not supported
      ABAP_CALL_NO_IXML_OBJECT
    • Hence, it's a bad idea to overwrite a standard message.
    • LO_ERROR->GET_TEXT( ) should be used instead.

Demo program for case 2:

 

REPORT zdemo.
CLASS ltcl_ DEFINITION FINAL
  FOR TESTING RISK LEVEL HARMLESS DURATION SHORT.

  PRIVATE SECTION.
    METHODS partially_transform_if_fails FOR TESTING RAISING cx_static_check.
ENDCLASS.


CLASS ltcl_ IMPLEMENTATION.
  METHOD partially_transform_if_fails.
    DATA message TYPE bapiret2.

    message = VALUE #( number = '001' ).
    TRY.
        CALL TRANSFORMATION id
             SOURCE XML `<asx:abap xmlns:asx="http://www.sap.com/abapxml" version="1.0"><asx:values><DATA><ID>AA</ID><NUMBER>AAA</NUMBER></DATA></asx:values></asx:abap>`
             RESULT data = message.
        cl_abap_unit_assert=>fail( 'The transformation was expected to fail'
           && ' because the message number cannot contain alpha AAA' ).
      CATCH cx_root INTO DATA(error).
        cl_abap_unit_assert=>assert_equals( act = message
                                            exp = VALUE bapiret2( id     = 'AA'
                                                                  number = '001' ) ).
    ENDTRY.
  ENDMETHOD.
ENDCLASS.

entry.title: Re: The position follow-up process failed because of an e...
entry.content:
Hi @zekeryaunal ,

Please check below information for troubleshooting and analysis of your issue.
In case none of below information can help with your issue, then please document your process end-to-end and share with Product Support Team.

Step-by-step troubleshooting checklist

Follow this sequence to pinpoint the cause quickly.
A. Verify process and template
  • Ensure you used the Global Assignment wizard (not Concurrent Employment).
  • Confirm the correct GA template is assigned and active.
B. Validate Event + Event Reason setup
  • Admin Center ‚Üí Manage Organization, Pay and Job Structures ‚Üí Event Reason:
    • Verify two dedicated Event Reasons exist and are Active:
      • For GA start (used by the wizard to write ‚ÄúAway on GA‚Äù on Home)
      • For GA return (used to write ‚ÄúBack from GA‚Äù on Home)
    • Check Employee Status on these Event Reasons (commonly remains ‚ÄúActive‚Äù for Home assignment while status is ‚ÄúAway on GA‚Äù at the assignment level).
    • Ensure RBP permissions include these Event Reasons for the acting user.
C. Validate Position Management ‚ÄúRight to Return‚Äù
  • Admin Center ‚Üí Position Management Settings ‚Üí Right to Return:
    • Ensure Right to Return is enabled.
    • Map the Event Reasons for Away/Back exactly to those from step B.
    • Confirm behavior for Home position during GA (reserve, allow other occupant, etc.) is consistent with your position capacity and multiple-incumbent settings.
  • Admin Center ‚Üí Position Management Settings ‚Üí General/Sync/Rules:
    • Review any Position Sync rules executed during GA start/end. Temporarily disable custom rules to test.
D. Check business rules and required fields
  • Admin Center ‚Üí Configure Business Rules:
    • Identify onSave/onChange rules for Job Information and Position that trigger on GA events.
    • Look for mandatory-set logic that could reject the Home ‚ÄúAway/Back‚Äù record or the position follow-up (for example, requires cost center or custom field that‚Äôs not set on Home at that time).
    • Temporarily deactivate non-critical rules and re-test to isolate the culprit.
E. Check permissions
  • RBP ‚Üí Role(s) of the acting user:
    • Job Information: Edit permission for the Home employment
    • Position object: View/Edit permission and field-level permission necessary for follow-up
    • Event Reasons used by GA (start/return)
  • If Centralized Services for Job Info is enabled, ensure the user has the right permissions to pass CS validations.
F. Use Admin Alerts and Execution Manager to get detail
  • Admin Center ‚Üí Admin Alerts:
    • Open the Position Follow-Up alert and view details; it often references which record/action failed.
    • After correcting config, use ‚ÄúRetrigger‚Äù as the alert suggests.
  • Admin Center ‚Üí Execution Manager:
    • Check any Global Assignment, Position Sync, or Centralized Services logs for stack messages pointing to missing mapping/permissions.

Quick remediation playbook

  • Most frequent fix:
    • Correctly map the Event Reasons for GA start/return in Position Management ‚Üí Right to Return.
    • Ensure those Event Reasons exist, are active, and have appropriate Employee Status settings.
    • Grant RBP to edit Job Info on the Home employment and to update Position during follow-up.
    • Retrigger the Admin Alert.
  • If still failing:
    • Temporarily disable custom Job Info/Position rules and retry; if success, reintroduce rules and fix the one that blocks the automated record creation.
    • Check multiple-incumbent and position capacity settings; align with your chosen Right-to-Return behavior.

Preventive best practices

  • Keep dedicated Event Reasons for GA Away/Back, and do not reuse them for unrelated processes.
  • Test GA with a minimal ruleset first; then layer custom rules to catch conflicts early.
  • Align Position Management multiple-incumbent/capacity rules with your Right-to-Return setting to avoid occupancy conflicts.
  • Document and permission the ‚Äúautomated‚Äù actor path for GA follow-up (who runs the action and what they can modify).

Hope this information can help you.

Regards.

Thiago Eva

entry.title: Re: Odata v4 batch request error
entry.content:
Hi,

Everything looks good except for the location: "ServiceContract & Position," which is repeated in all requests.

Have you tried using the OData V4 receiver adapter with the "Batch Send" option instead of HTTP? I used OData V4 Batch for creation and update operations, and it worked well‚Äîwith the caveat that I couldn't match requests to responses in the response body. There was no information returned for matching, so I had to rely on the order of requests matching the order of responses. Fortunately, the first record in the request corresponded to the first in the response, the second to the second, and so on.

This might be a good workaround for you as well if option with Odata V4 will not work as well for this specific S/4H API.

Best regards,
Mateusz

entry.title: Re: how to book Prepaid expenses and amortize over period...
entry.content:
Hello @mallela_pavankumar21 

Thank you for your question

The public cloud provides two standard options to book prepaid expenses and amortize them based on the number of days. The one you may consider as ‚Äúbest‚Äù depends on whether you want full automation with a posting run, or a simpler, controlled recurring posting approach.

The best practice which is also Option 1 is to Manage Accruals with Accrual Engine. This handles prepaid expenses with start date and end date. Then it lets the system post periodic deferral and expense recognition. See Accrual/Deferral of Expenses and Revenues and Blog: Processing of Prepayments with SAP S/4HANA Accruals Management

Also, this video tutorial provides some good insights: https://learning.sap.com/videos/managing-accruals-and-deferrals-in-sap-accruals-management-with-sap-s-4hana-cloud-public-edition

For this option you need to ensure your set up is done.

The first step here is to:

  1. Confirm you are using Accruals Management/ Accrual Engine in your tenant. If not, you have to enable it through scope and configuration.
  2. Ensure you have a delivered accrual item type and method for deferrals (prepaid expenses). See KBA 3567857 for more information.

Second step:

Your source document should be for

Debit: prepaid expense account (balance sheet)

Credit: Vendor

Third step:

  • You have to create an accrual or deferral object for your invoice in accrual app (e.g., Manage Accruals)
  • You must maintain a start and end date (within the same period)
  • You must choose a deferral method that supports time-based distribution.

Fourth step:

Here you need to use the standard run app to calculate and post the periodic amounts. You normally do this during your monthly close. This will allow your system to post the expense recognition and reduce the prepaid balance. See Accrual/Deferral of Expenses and Revenues.

Fifth step:

Is for you to validate and report by using journal entry reporting for the periods and reconciling prepaid balance against the remaining service period.

 

The common option 2 is to use recurring journal entries with day-based proration per month. See  Post Recurring Journal Entries and  Manage Recurring Journal Entries for more details.

If you cannot get true day-based proration from your accrual method in public cloud, the clean workaround is to:

  • Book the prepaid invoice once
  • Then post monthly expense recognition using recurring journal entries
  • Prorate each month by the number of service days in that month

Step 1: In your Manage Recurring Journal Entries, create a recurring entry (Debit expense account and Credit prepaid expense account), set the dates you want to run

Step 2 is to make sure you base it on days. Because months have different day counts, you either:

 

Create separate recurring entries per month with the exact amount, or you use one recurring entry and manually adjust the monthly posting (not my preference)

Let me illustrate that:

Let‚Äôs say your prepaid amount is 12,000 for service, the period involved is 15 Jan to 14 April (90 days).

Daily rate = 12,000/90 = 133.33 per day.

Then your monthly postings will be:

Jan: 17 days (15 to 31) x 133.33 =2,266.61

Feb: 28 days x 133.33 = 3,733.24

Mar: --> (same)

Apr: --> (same)


Third step:

Is to schedule automatic posting jobs by using See  Post Recurring Journal Entries to automatically create monthly postings.

 

In summary:

  • You should pick option 1 if you want the system to manage the schedule and calculation based on start and end dates. It also gives you the accrual method that supports your required distribution logic.
  • You can pick option 2 if you need strict day-based proration and your available accrual methods do not prorate by calendar days.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Display configuration values by user login language i...
entry.content:
To display configuration values based on the user's login language in SAP CPQ Quote 2.0, you will need to make use of the language-dependent configuration features within the system. Here's a general approach to achieve this:

  1. Use User Locale/Language Settings:
    The system typically picks up the user‚Äôs login language from the locale settings in their profile. You can leverage this information in your configuration rules to display values specific to that language.

  2. Configure Translations:
    In SAP CPQ, each configurable product or value should have translation tables where you can store different values or descriptions based on languages. You can set up translations for your configuration fields directly in the product configuration setup. This ensures that when a user logs in with a particular language, the appropriate values are displayed.

  3. Conditional Logic:
    You might need to create conditional logic (such as using rules or scripts) that will pull the correct configuration values depending on the user‚Äôs language. This can be set up via the CPQ scripting engine to dynamically load the appropriate data.

  4. Testing:
    Make sure to test this with different user profiles, changing their login language, to ensure that the correct configuration values appear based on their selected language.

  5. Documentation:
    Don‚Äôt forget to check SAP‚Äôs official documentation for Quote 2.0, as they often provide language-specific guidelines or enhancements that can be useful.

If you run into any specific issues with setting this up, it's a good idea to check the CPQ community forums or reach out to SAP support, as there might be nuances depending on your version or specific setup.

entry.title: Re: How to apply a filter on a single property of a data...
entry.content:
Hi @Dan_Wroblewski,

Let me bring more details to clarify. Actually, the app variable where we store the account technical IDs has already been created:

Once we retrieve the account technical IDs, we set the above variable as follows:

Then, we set the filter condition of the Get Record Collection as follows:

The formula "as is" works fine but as you can see, we filter the data entity using only the first account technical ID of the array (see appVars.collectedAccountTechnicalIds[0].accountTechnicalId). The result of this is that only the cases of the data set whose account.id field is the first occurence of the collectedAccountTechnicalIds variable are displayed.
 
In this particular case, we have 3 account technical IDs stored in the app variable:
 
[{"accountTechnicalId":"11f01ec7-9077-32de-afdb-816548020a00"},
{"accountTechnicalId":"11f01ec7-908d-c81e-afdb-817b0a020a00"},
{"accountTechnicalId":"11f01ec7-8ea9-ecee-afdb-817b0a020a00"}]
 
So, our question is: using the above formula, is there a way to filter the data entity using all the values stored in the array?
 
We tried using the following formula too {type: "and", conditions: [{type: "eq", property: ["account.id"], value: appVars.collectedAccountTechnicalIds}]} as you can see below, but it returns the following error message {"code":"unknown","status":-1,"message":"TypeError: e.replace is not a function","rawError":{}}
Thanks,
 
LM.

entry.title: Re: Report using the "Main Account" field in account header
entry.content:
I found the solution to my problem myself, and I'm here to share it with everyone. üòÖ

If you filter on selection the field "Main Account" in "Advanced" -> "Contains" -> "X", the data source will display the expected behavior. This filter will provide preference for "Main Accounts" (For accounts that have one) and will count accounts that don't have the flag as well. 

Cl√≥vis M√ºller

entry.title: Re: Is the CAP Error Handling approach of "Let It Crash" the right one?
entry.content:
I agree with this to a certain extent, but I think the statement needs some nuance, especially in the context of Node.js applications exposed to external users.

Could you share a concrete example or real-world scenario where not letting the process crash actually led to issues like memory leaks, stuck resources, corrupted state, or unpredictable behavior?

In practice, it‚Äôs not always feasible to simply let the process die. In an HTTP server, for example, a user can repeatedly trigger the same failing request. If the process crashes every time, you can easily end up in a loop like:

  • invalid request

  • process crash

  • restart 

  • same request again

  • crash again

This can lead to:

  • constant service instability

  • higher infrastructure costs

  • overall system degradation, especially behind load balancers

In those cases, isolating the error to the request, responding properly, and keeping the process alive is often the most pragmatic approach.

The original statement makes more sense for cases like:

  • errors during initialization

  • failures affecting shared global state

  • unhandled errors outside controlled async boundaries

  • native module or memory corruption issues

But saying that crashing is always the right approach can be dangerous in systems that handle untrusted or high-volume traffic.

If you have a specific example (e.g., memory leaks caused by unhandled promise rejections, open handles, inconsistent pools), it would be great to discuss where a crash-only strategy truly makes sense versus where error isolation is safer.

entry.title: From AI Ideas to Tangible Business Value
entry.content:
How to turn AI ambition into real traction ‚Äî with the right methodology

Artificial intelligence is firmly embedded in enterprise strategies today.
What many organizations still struggle with, however, is turning AI ambition into operational value.

Too many initiatives stall at proof-of-concept stage, create isolated solutions, or deliver impressive demos without enabling real business decisions. Over time, this erodes trust ‚Äî in technology, in delivery models, and sometimes even in IT leadership.
The key question is therefore no longer ‚ÄúWhat could we do with AI?‚Äù
It is:

How do we move from a real business problem to a confident go / no-go decision ‚Äî quickly, responsibly, and with the organization on board?

Why this matters now

AI is no longer an innovation topic. It is a leadership and transformation topic.

Today, AI initiatives compete with limited organizational change capacity, ongoing cloud transformations, rising expectations from business leaders, and increasing pressure to deliver visible results.

The real risk is not moving too slowly.
It is moving fast in the wrong direction ‚Äî creating fragmented solutions, undermining trust, or introducing AI faster than the organization can absorb it.

What companies need now is not more experimentation, but a repeatable way to turn AI ideas into informed decisions, aligned with enterprise standards and grounded in real business needs.

Problem first ‚Äî not technology first

Successful AI use cases do not start with models, tools, or platforms.
They start with concrete business pain points: high manual effort, lack of transparency, time pressure in critical phases, or uncertainty in decision-making.

This is exactly where proven innovation approaches such as the SAP AppHaus come in. The focus is on understanding and framing the problem first, prioritizing what really matters ‚Äî and only then discussing solutions.

This shift sounds simple, but it fundamentally changes outcomes.

Humanize, visualize and validate with Scenes from SAP AppHaus

From idea to decision: rapid prototyping with SAP Mode 2 Garage

The examples below were implemented using the SAP Mode 2 Garage.

A Mode 2 Garage is a highly focused, time-boxed format in which customers work together with SAP to analyze a concrete business problem, define clear goals and success criteria, build a working prototype, and create a solid decision basis for next steps.

Methodologically, the Mode 2 Garage combines AppHaus principles ‚Äî problem focus, user centricity, co-innovation ‚Äî with hands-on implementation together with SAP Services, the customer, and end users.

The outcome is not a concept.
It is clarity.

Two example use cases from practice

Use case 1: AI-supported user guidance in procurement

In large organizations, many procurement needs arise outside the daily routine ‚Äî often from people who do not regularly work with procurement processes. These needs are not necessarily complex, but they are unfamiliar.

Typical situations include one-time service requests, non-catalog purchases, questions around existing framework agreements, or time-critical requests with limited process knowledge.

As a result, procurement teams face high manual effort, inconsistent data quality, and avoidable delays ‚Äî not because functionality is missing, but because guidance is missing at the moment of need.

Implementation approach (high level)

The prototype was built around a chat-based user interface on the SAP Business Technology Platform, serving as a central entry point for users.

A custom chatbot captured requests in natural language. Uploaded quotations and documents were analyzed and grounded with enterprise context using the SAP GenAI Hub. Instead of generating generic answers, AI responses were enriched with structured enterprise knowledge. Relevant SAP backend systems were integrated to retrieve information such as applicable framework agreements, category-specific rules, approval thresholds, and historical purchasing patterns.

Critical decision points remained explicitly human-in-the-loop. AI was positioned as guidance and decision support ‚Äî not automation.

The solution was implemented modularly, extensible, and aligned with standard processes.

Outcome and time-to-value

Even at prototype stage, the solution delivered tangible value: fewer follow-up questions to procurement, improved data quality at the point of request, and higher user acceptance through guided interaction.

Based on clear decision readiness, the solution was further developed and went live in less than one year.
The prototype did not just validate an idea ‚Äî it became the springboard into productive use.

Outlook

Looking ahead, this approach is well suited to be integrated into SAP Joule as a custom-built Joule skill, embedding AI-supported procurement guidance directly into daily workflows while retaining full control over enterprise context, governance, and process logic.

Use case 2: AI-supported GR/IR reconciliation in finance closing

Although the company was already running on SAP S/4HANA, GR/IR reconciliation was still largely handled in the traditional SAP GUI way. Transparency on open cases was limited, analysis effort was high, and closing periods were stressful for finance and procurement alike.

The challenge was not missing functionality, but handling complexity efficiently and consistently.

Step 1: Standard first

The first deliberate step was not AI, but the introduction of the standard GR/IR Monitoring and Reconciliation Fiori app. This alone improved transparency, established a shared working basis, and clarified ownership across teams.

Step 2: Targeted AI extension

Building on the standard, a complementary custom Fiori app was prototyped to address the hard cases: unmatched GR/IR positions, unclear root causes, and high manual clarification effort.

SAP standard remained the system of record. AI was applied selectively where complexity arose. Document AI analyzed invoices and supporting documents, while generative AI summarized context and suggested next best actions. Importantly, AI did not post accounting entries ‚Äî it supported expert decision-making by structuring information and proposing options.

Positioning towards the SAP standard

Comparable capabilities will increasingly become available through embedded AI capabilities and SAP Joule as part of SAP‚Äôs roadmap. In this case, however, Joule was not yet an option due to missing cloud readiness in the current system landscape.

The prototype therefore deliberately served as a bridge to the standard ‚Äî delivering short-term value, enabling organizational learning, and preparing for future adoption of standard SAP capabilities, without creating a long-term parallel solution.

Current status

Around six months after the prototype, the use case is in business testing and validation, with a strong focus on trust, plausibility, and acceptance.

The biggest challenge is not AI ‚Äî it's change

Across both use cases, one insight stood out clearly: the biggest hurdle is not technology, data, or architecture ‚Äî it is change management.

For readers who want to dive deeper into AI concepts such as grounding, document AI, or retrieval-augmented generation (RAG), SAP provides a comprehensive reference with its AI Best Practices on SAP BTP.

In practice, however, success depended less on technology and more on how people adapted. Introducing AI changes how users trust recommendations, interact with systems, make decisions, and let go of familiar routines.

Rapid prototyping played a crucial role by creating a safe learning environment ‚Äî allowing teams to build confidence before scaling.

Key takeaways

  • AI initiatives need a decision goal, not just a technical objective

  • Standard-first approaches build trust and accelerate adoption

  • Prototypes create value when they enable organizational learning

  • Change management must start on day one

  • AI succeeds when people become comfortable using it

Conclusion: methodology beats actionism

AI does not fail because of technology.
It fails when organizations move faster than their people.

Clear methodology, rapid prototyping, and early change management are what turn AI from strategic intent into operational value.

Want to try this approach yourself?
Join our upcoming customer hackathon

For customers who want to explore AI pragmatically and advance concrete use cases, we are organizing  customer hackathons.

The format follows the same core principles as the SAP Mode 2 Garage: real business problems, cross-functional teams, rapid prototyping, and a strong focus on decision readiness rather than demo perfection.

The hackathons will take place in Berlin, Munich, Vienna, and Zurich.

üëâInterested?
Learn more about the hackathons and register here: Hackathon ‚Äì Business meets AI

If you would like to discuss the methodologies, formats, and tools described in this article feel free to reach out directly via email or LinkedIn.

entry.title: Purchase Order Form - language for countries
entry.content:
The purchase order output displays incorrect country names in French and German languages instead of English, despite the supplier and plant configurations being set to English.


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Purchase Order Form - language for countries
entry.content:
Hi,

In Purchase Order outputs where the supplier address and the ship-to (delivery) address are located in different countries, SAP applies international postal regulations when determining the language of the country names:

  • The country name of an address may be displayed in a language that ensures correct identification and processing by international postal services.

  • As a result, the country field can appear in a different language than the supplier master language, plant language, or overall PO output language.

This behavior is by design and applies to standard Purchase Order output templates in SAP S/4HANA Cloud as per KBA

https://me.sap.com/notes/0002836612

Thanks,

SAP Support
